With a week remaining, the rate is at 1.22 and has been trending downward for the past week. The rate was already considered overextended by a number of observers, so rebound seems unlikely. This is particularly true since repatriation of EUR currency held by US firms is likely to continue to take place as firms repatriate funds to take advantage of the new tax laws. At the same time, extensive losses seem unlikely; barring a massive external event, there's no reason to expect a major drop that would be needed to take the rate below 1.10. However, the downward trend has been slow and shows some volatility, and the cutoff figure of 1.20 is right in the middle of what I'd consider to be the most likely endpoint - somewhere between 1.18 and 1.21.

Given the uncertainty associated with any kind of US government policy, Fed and the Treasury can only do so much to create a steady, stable , and predictable macro environment.  And since official US policy is to not have a policy concerning USD exchange rate levels vs. any other currency, then markets will have their way. Thus, while there's always a chance the dollar will strengthen against the euro, I think the most likely outcome is for the dollar to weaken against other major foreign currencies in the next month or so other things being equal.

With a persistent 1.20 resistance level, and a likely hike in interest rates in the US coming in December (and therefore a stronger dollar compared to the Euro), a close above 1.20 for the Euro is, I think, less and less likely.
https://www.usatoday.com/story/money/2017/11/20/fed-meeting-minutes-could-cement-december-hike/874463001/

Time to put some markers here for the post-mortem evaluation. What are the main drivers of this exchange rate in this timeframe?  - on the US side, the main one seems to be the tax package. Its passage in some form should boost the dollar (through expectations of a short-term fiscal impulse, which should lead to higher interest rates). There is a small chance that the final package may disappoint if it is seen as too timid relative to market expectations. And, of course, if nothing gets passed, the dollar will suffer. But I think this is a small chance as well.  - on the other hand, the Fed's policy that is baked in the cake seems clear - a hike in December, followed by another one no earlier than June 2018, plus the already announced gradual reduction of the balance sheet. So only deviations from this plan can produce news for the exchange rate. Unlikely for now. - on the European side, the news until Feb 15 are likely to be mainly political - the German situation, the Brexit discussions (to some extent), and, towards the end, expectations about the Italian elections.  I think at present the markets expect positive outcomes in all three, so the risks are on the downside.

Reason
- CME EUR FX futures price converges toward EURUSD spot price when approaching expiry
- Last trade price for CME EUR FX futures (January 2018) was 1.18905 as at 2017-09-29 21:38:04 UTC
- Between 1998-12-31 and 2017-09-29, the high and low for EURUSD spot price was 1.5997 and 0.8276 respectively
- Mean spot price between 1998-12-31 and 2017-09-29 is 1.2086
- Mean spot price between 2016-10-03 and 2017-09-29 is 1.1049 Assumption
- EURUSD spot price is mean reverting Critique
- There may be a large spread between CME EUR FX futures price and EURUSD spot price Source

I always root against the Euro, but rarely against Europe.  Nowadays, when I see the exchange rate, I yearn for a European vacation.  The US and Europe are experiencing simultaneous instability, but the EU is much more complicated and fragile than the US currently.  The European Central Bank and the Federal Reserve are on different pages as of now, but their differences will likely be less consequential to currency value the day after Valentine's day next year.  World events seem as if they will be the driving force of currency value at that point in time.
Europena economy is getting better. US showed some weaknes in data.

Factors likely to affect the EUR/US$ exchange rate in this time frame:  - expected changes in interest rate differentials: with euro are yields currently more compressed than US ones, the reduction in monetary accommodation by the ECB in coming months would reduce the difference in sovereign bond yields between European and US bonds, supporting the euro (as in the last two weeks). The Fed plans are well known by now, and if anything risks are for slower interest rate hikes than expected by the markets (if the Fed gives priority to reducing its balance sheet);  - cyclical position of the US and euro area economies: the euro area is a couple of years behind the US in their cyclical recovery, so the pick-up in economic activity has probably longer to run there. This would induce capital flows to Europe, again supporting the euro;  - tax cut package in the US: this will probably appear for discussion in the fall, but the main points are already known from the one-pager published in April. Normally, this should push the US bond yields up, supporting the dollar (as it did after the US elections), but the second time around the effect would be muted, I think;  - trade barriers in the US, if such are introduced: by harming US economic activity, this should push US interest rates and the dollar down.  Much of this is already anticipated, hence the recent EUR/US$ exchange rate of 1.14. Still, most factors would seem to push for weaker dollar rather than a stronger one.

On a short break to Barcelona in May 2010, I sent a postcard of Miro's Aidez L'Espagne to my team with just 1.17 written on the back.  With a long term range then of maybe 1.25 to 1.45, 1.17 was intended as shocking number, and "aidez" was indeed required, and a few years later, has broadly succeeded.  Europe now has a better opportunity to catch up to its trend growth line / cyclical recovery, and Macron has to be a more exciting value play than Trump, just because the scope of his reforms are considerably smaller to exceed expectations and improve trend growth. Which leaves central bank policy, and the intriguing question of who figures out how to unwind asset purchases first, the Fed or ECB?  The possibility is certainly there of hawkish ECB members pushing  for the Dali-esque experimentation of QE to begin to reverse while the Fed dithers.  And then we are back to a 1.25-1.45 range, not .9 to 1.2.

Seems to be more upside then downside so decreasing below $.90 and increasing between $ 1.1-1.2 by 5%.

EU likely to continue to outperform expectations. ECB likely to commence tapering asset purchases in the next 12 months.  Further USD strength relies on pace of interest rate increases - likely to undershoot market expectations.

Upside factors:
- Retreating political risk in France, and Germany (Schultz is even more Euro positive than Merkel)
- Improving economy and rising inflation
- Further tapering of ECB asset purchases during H2 2017 expected, and could even have talk of a hike to the deposit rate in Q1 2018
- Increasing uncertainty about ability of Trump administration to deliver promised fiscal stimulus
- Slight slowdown in US growth vs EU growth Downside factors:
- New political risks in Italy (although elections are not scheduled until May 2018), with possible victory of euro-skeptic Five Star Movement
- NPL problem, especially in Italy, a risk to the banking sector, and continued need for Greece bailouts
- 2-3 hikes to Fed funds rates before deadline (although the talk is currently more dovish) Conclusion: slightly more bullish on Euro, and medium-term level is probably above $1.10. Risk of Eurozone break-up is still lingering though.

Base case scenario is for continued labor tightness and modest economic growth in the US to keep the Fed on path to tighten 2 - 3 more times between April 17 and Feb 18. Inflation in US could average 2.5%. ECB will remain very accommodative as Brexit and looming Italian election creates uncertainty. Expect $ to strengthen towards, but not through parity.  If not base case: If Europe strengths through forecast period Euro could head back towards PPP = ~115. If nationalist sentiments grow, Greece becomes a bigger problem, Brexit negotiations go poorly or Italian polls tilt towards a nationalist party, Euro could head through parity.

What will be the end-of-day closing value for the euro against the U.S. dollar on 15 February 2018?
Forecast: Between $0.90 and $1: 20%, between $1 and $1.10: 75%, between $1.10 and $1.20: 5%, by Ruben van den Akker on the 11th of April 2017
The information shown in figure 1 is the exchange rate of the euro against the US dollar since the implementation of the euro, indicating how much one needs to pay in dollars to get one euro. It becomes clear from the graph that from 2001 to 2009, the euro was getting stronger relative to the dollar, however, since then the dollar has gradually increased in value compared to the euro. Where €1 was $1.60 in 2008, the current exchange rate is €1 for $1.058. 
One indicator for the exchange rate of either the dollar or the euro is the interest rate. Governments of every country give out bonds to finance their expenses, in return the buyers get a certain yield. If the interest rate is high, the bond yields are also high and therefore more attractive. Figure 3 shows the yield of a bond with a maturity of 10 years of the United States and figure for shows the same for Germany. As one can see, the yield on US treasury bonds is much higher than the yield on German bonds and therefore buyers are more inclined to purchase the former. Germany is used as an example here because it is the biggest economy in the EU and bonds are issued by governments and not by the European Union. In for example Greece the yield on bonds is much higher, yet this brings a higher risk for the buyer as well. When investors from outside the US buy US treasury bonds, they exchange the currency of their country for US dollars. In other words, they sell their currency and buy dollars. As a result, if the yield on treasury bonds of the US is higher than those o f Germany and other EU countries, then the demand for the US Dollar will increase relative to the demand for euros, which will lead to a lower value of the euro against US dollars.
Another strong indicator for developments in the exchange rate is trade. When a country exports a good, the demand for their currency will rise, whilst when importing a good the supply of their currency will rise. Keeping all other factors constant the former situation will lead to an appreciation of the dollar and the latter to a depreciation. In figure 5 the trade balance of the United States is shown, it becomes clear that there is an apparent trade deficit. President of the United States Donald Trump has indicated on many occasions that he finds this unacceptable and he has devised a plan to improve the trade balance. If this plan works out, there will be more export of US goods relative to import of goods to the US, resulting in an appreciation of the dollar. However, there is much uncertainty about whether Trump will succeed in decreasing the trade deficit. In Europe (figure 6) the general trend since 2010 seems to be a positive and improving trade balance over the past couple of years, yet at the moment  there is a substantial down fall. If the trend continues then this will lead to an appreciation of the euro in the coming years, keeping all other factors constant.
In conclusion, there is much uncertainty about what the value of the euro against the dollar will be next year. The bond yields give a clear indication of a strong US dollar relative to the euro, yet the trade balance and the Trump effect are much more ambiguous. My forecast will be that I expect the dollar to appreciate a little compared to the euro and therefore I estimate the chances of the value of the euro against the dollar to be between $1 and $1.10 70%. Furthermore I indicate a 20% chance for the value to be between $0.90 and a $15% chance for the value to be between $1.10 and $1.20.
Draghi is going to continue to support the Bond purchases and Germany is going to keep pushing for a lower Euro, thus a much narrower range for a longer period.
Political instability could be the downside risk, though I am more inclined to more countries realizing the benefits of the union outweigh the prospects of going it alone.

Major currency pairs like this one just don't move that much over the short term, or even over longer runs. The euro has been between $1.00 and $1.10 since November and spent virtually all the remainder of 2016 between $1.10 and $1.15. So I'm expecting this trend to continue and the euro to end up somewhere around $1.10.

The Euro last was below parity in 2002. It tends to fall against the dollar when there is a financial crisis (2000 - 2002, 2008) because of the perception that the dollar is a safe haven (or at least foreign dollars flow home to be converted into U.S. treasuries).  Two more U.S. rate hikes in 2017 plus one more potentially in 2018, raising the U.S. dollar. On the other hand, ECB has made some noise about hiking their overnight deposit rate as well. Still, US economy is doing better than Europe's so it's more likely to have the U.S. Fed move faster than the ECB. On the trade side, the Trump administration may scrap or rewrite agreements, hurting trade and devaluing the U.S. dollar. However, there is also populism rising in Europe which may also make it harder for Europe to sign new trade agreements, or even have to renegotiate new agreements.  On the balance of probabilities, the U.S. dollar appears to have more tailwinds than the Euro. On the other hand, parity is a huge psychological barrier so it will encounter more resistance than normal. (March 2017)
They both may go down, so where does that leave us?

The price took a big drop a couple years ago, and since then its been slowing trending downward.  The Fed is very likely to raise rates three more times this year.  Tough to see the Eurozone matching even one of those moves.  So we have to see the exchange rate going downward, all other things being equal.  That is what I think is going to finally drive the price below 1.04, which has been a strong support for about two years now.  Once through that we have parity, which is usually a big psychological barrier.  But my bet is that even that will be pierced during the next nine months.  Going below 0.90 seems tough.  More than 1.20 seems virtually impossible, unless we have a major adverse event that would be complicated to even elucidate, much less predict.  Given the overall downtrend, between 1.10 and 1.20 seems very unlikely also.  The range to focus on are the bottom three.   FX predictions are really tough.  Best we can do is go with the flow and stay within reasonable bounds.

Less than $0.90 seems to require either significant problems in the Eurozone (i.e. another financial crisis but somehow restricted to the EU, or would require one of the more prosperous EU member states to exit) or a significant US border tax/VAT. As a result it seems less likely than the more moderate options of $0.90-1.10 (which are close to status quo, with some downward mobility in the case that the EU continues to grow more slowly than the US). The case for $1.10-1.20 requires no border tax in the US and a significant devaluation of the dollar (corresponding to inflationary policy), which requires the Federal Reserve to lose its independence or significantly change its goals, neither of which seem likely. More than $1.20 seems correspondingly less likely.

The Trump administration want a cheaper USD to support the reductions of their trade deficits, but there's only so much they can do to fight the fundamentals, including three rate hikes by the Fed and an notable uptick in inflation  driven by rising oil and energy prices, especially outside the US.  On the other side, Europe faces an unprecedented number of downsize risks in 2017, with both the survival of the EU and the Eurozone a real question, should populists come to power in France and Italy. The uncertainty created by the political risks, coupled with negative policy rates by the ECB until at least end of 2018, and the ongoing asset purchase programs until end of 2017, will push the Euro downwards. USD-EUR parity should be achieved and we might go even below that.  A slight caveat is that by 15 Feb 2018 we will have a clearer picture of many of these uncertainties, including what a EU without the UK will look like, hence the Euro might have rebounded somewhat.

At the same time, some strategists believe the euro is very undervalued, and could head towards $1.30 if there is not an extreme negative event in the Eurozone.  My forecast accounts for these extreme possible outcomes.
